facts.text: Appellants carrying on business at Raha in Nowgong District had dealings with respondents carrying on business at Gauhati, resulting in appellants indebted to respondents in Rs. 9,447-4-9.

Appellants sent cheque for Rs. 9,461-4-0 dated August 31, 1948 to respondents; cheque drawn by Messrs. Nathuram Jaidayal of Sibsagar on Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar Branch, in favour of appellants, endorsed to respondents.
On September 4, 1948, respondents sent cheque to their bankers, Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati for collection.
Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati sent cheque to Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar for encashment on same day.

Tripura Modern Bank, Sibsagar debited accounts of Messrs. Nathuram Jaidayal with Rs. 9,461-4-0, deducted Rs. 6-4-0 commission, sent draft for Rs. 9,435/- dated September 14, 1948 to Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati; draft drawn on Calcutta Head Office, current for three months.
Calcutta Commercial Bank, Gauhati sent draft to Head Office at Calcutta for collection but never presented it; no attempts to collect.
Respondents wrote to appellants that cash payment for cheque not received; appellants replied on September 18, 1948 asking respondents to get back the cheque, but cheque never returned.
Calcutta Commercial Bank closed business on September 17, 1948, later wound up.
Tripura Modern Bank closed business on October 16, 1948, entered scheme of arrangement with creditors.
On November 19, 1948, respondents requested Tripura Modern Bank to pay draft amount to them, not Calcutta Commercial Bank; no payment made.
Respondents instituted suit on March 8, 1949 claiming dues from appellants as cheque was conditional payment and not cashed.
Subordinate Judge, Lower Assam District dismissed suit.
High Court in First Appeal No. 7 of 1962 reversed trial court, decreed suit, judgment dated May 21, 1957.

P.W. 3 (employee of Calcutta Commercial Bank) stated draft sent by registered post to head office, returned undelivered as head office closed; draft would have been paid if presented before October 16, 1948.
Appellants wrote letter dated September 10, 1949 to respondents acknowledging non-receipt and asking to get cheque back.

legal_issues.text: Whether the cheque was received as conditional payment, and if the original debt revived due to non-payment, or if laches in collecting the draft discharged the appellants.
Whether acceptance of the draft by respondents' bank constituted absolute payment of the cheque.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondents accepted cheque as conditional payment but failed to present draft for payment within reasonable time, causing prejudice to appellants due to bank closures; laches discharge the debt.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Chitty on Contracts 22nd Edn. Art. 1079; Addisons Treatise on Contracts 11th Edn. p.156; Hopkins v. Ware; Chamberlain v. Delarive

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondents' bank accepted demand draft on September 14, 1948 as absolute payment of the cheque, discharging appellants' liability.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Chalmers on Bills of Exchange p.301 12th ed.; strong presumption in favour of conditional payment unless accepted as absolute

respondent_arguments.text: Cheque was conditional payment; non-cashing revives original claim; failure to obtain payment of draft not due to their laches.
Appellants' letter dated September 10, 1949 admits liability on cheque.

court_reasoning.text: High Court rightly held cheque conditional, but respondents' laches in collecting draft (kept without presentation, no attempts despite 3-month validity) prejudiced appellants as draft payable before bank closure; deemed retained as absolute payment, debt discharged.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Duty to present within reasonable time; failure alters debtor's position for worse.

court_reasoning.text: Respondents through agents received draft instead of cash; acceptance in course of collection equivalent to direct acceptance as conditional; failure to present caused prejudice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Draft payable before October 16, 1948; P.W.3 evidence confirms payment would have been made.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred in assuming Tripura Modern Bank closed September 16 (fact October 16) and no prejudice to appellants.
Separate by Mudholkar J.: Respondents accepted draft as absolute payment; letter Nov 19, 1948 confirms; cheque honoured by debit, draft issued at instance; rights shift to draft, not original debt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presumption conditional overcome by acceptance of draft; appellants' letter in ignorance.

holdings.text: Cheque treated as duly paid via draft retention due to laches; original debt discharged.
Acceptance of demand draft deemed absolute payment.

precedents_cited.relevance: Creditor taking third-party cheque must present within reasonable time or debtor discharged if prejudiced.
Creditor holding draft unreasonable time before demand, drawer insolvent: creditor's loss.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment and decree set aside, trial court judgment and decree restored. Respondents pay costs in Supreme Court; parties bear own costs below.
outcome.costs: Respondents pay costs in this Court; parties pay and bear own costs in courts below.

key_quotes.text: "the respondents must be deemed to have retained the draft as absolute payment of the cheque, and on the payment of the cheque, the original debt stood discharged."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on laches and discharge of debt.

key_quotes.text: "Where a negotiable instrument... is accepted by the creditor as conditional payment, he is bound to do all that a holder... may do in order to get payment... if he fails... the creditor is guilty of laches and makes the cheque his own."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States legal principle from Chitty applied.

key_quotes.text: "the respondents by accepting the demand draft... must be deemed to have accepted that draft as a legal tender or as absolute payment."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Mudholkar J.'s reasoning on absolute payment.
